Good Newman film - taut energy - the strength of the film lies in Newman's portrayal of Lucas Jackson, a non-conformist who under most circumstances wouldn't even be considered a criminal. But he's paying the price for a drunken jag resulting in some damaged parking meters, and without trying, ingratiates himself with fellow prisoners following a physical beating at the hands of fellow prisoner Dragline (George Kennedy). That confrontation sets up the story for Luke's repeated attempts at escaping not only from the work farm, but from his own restless sense of being a prisoner in his own skin. Director Stuart Rosenberg magnifies Luke's struggle for redemption in the strongly imaged fade out right after the egg eating contest, showing the prone Newman in a crucifixion pose with arms outstretched and legs akimbo.Newman's not the only standout in the picture though. George Kennedy earned a Best Supporting Actor trophy for his portrayal of Dragline, the nominal head of the prisoners who is so inspired by Luke's work ethic and integrity that he eventually comes around to calling him 'my boy'. Strother Martin also makes an impact as the prison captain, and I wonder now if his signature line in the picture, which is now a staple of middle managers and parents everywhere, was the first time it was ever used - "What we have here, is failure to communicate".To be sure, there are a lot of great scenes in "Cool Hand Luke" - the fight, the car wash, the egg eating contest, the escapes. I myself could watch Carr the floor walker (Clifton James) over and over again as he explains what it takes to earn a night in the box.

I watched Cool Hand Luke as part of my Existential philosophy class I was taking this past spring. While I had heard of the movie, I never took the time to watch it before this class. What a great movie with a lot of symbolism. I watched this movie and immediately saw the character of Luke as Freidrich Nietzsche might have seen him, an overman type that had come as close as maybe anyone to using his own "will to power" if you will. While I am a fan of Nietzsche, I also saw other points of other philosophers as well, even Nietzsche's opposite Kierkegaard and others like Heidegger and Camus. Maybe this movie was intended to be philosophical and maybe it wasn't, but I enjoyed it either way and recommend it to anyone regardless of their feelings of life or philosophy.

Existentialism has been part of literature and movies ever since it was popularized by the likes of Jean-Paul Sartre and other French Philosophers.I've seen many movies which can be interpreted as having existentialist or postmodernist (Nihilistic) tendencies. I myself can't stand movies having nihilistic themes such as 'Pulp Fiction',although these movies have been quite a success at the big screen and no body feels reluctant to call them 'Blockbuster'. Existentialism on the other hand is not as hopeless a philosophy (If you consider it a philosophy) as Nihilism.Existentialism in a nutshell is philosophy 'individualized'.Its emphasis on human freedom and liberty is such that it has attracted many creative writers and film makers.The influence of existentialism spreads beyond the realm of philosophy. 'Cool Hand Luke',staring one of my favorite actors Paul Newman stands up as a movie which can surely belong to existential genre.The movie surrounds around one man's defiance against authority .The protagonist from start of the movie till its end ,struggles to get himself free.The problem with the most of the people is that they give up pretty quickly but the problem with our hero is that he never gives up.He can be described as a person who consciously makes all those efforts to get himself free,but is unconsciously aware about his futile efforts.Any person who have special affinity towards 'Existentialism' must see this masterpiece.Had Sartre reviewed this movie he would only have used one sentence to end it all,the sentence would surely have been ,'Man is condemned to be free'.But I will end my review with the tag line of the movie,'What we've got here is a failure to communicate'.

Like most people, I love excellent movies and the actors responsible for making them excellent. Graced by a stellar cast, this is the epitome of one of those excellent movies. Strother Martin had a never failing genius when it came to portraying southern cads, regardless of what level of society he represented. And as the cruel warden in this film he is just as wonderfully entertaining as his fans have learned to expect. Casting the amazing Jo Van Fleet in the cameo role as Luke's mother in failing health on a last visit was a thoughtful touch, adding depth and understanding to Luke's personal turmoil. Anyone who has seen her brilliant effort as the defiant elderly landowner (Van Fleet was actually 46 at the time) in Elia Kazan's Wild River would expect no less. George Kennedy turns in his usual stellar performance as the big tough, but not too bright prison ringleader. His best-supporting Oscar was well deserved. The only disappointment I have as I watch and re-watch this great movie, is the fact that the utterly fantastic performance by Paul Newman as the born loser who throughout the film was called upon to exhibit the extreme highs and low of human emotion, and did so with amazing realism, went home without the Oscar. He truly deserved an Oscar for this role.

This movie is in my opinion one of the greatest ever made. To sum it up in short, recall the cliché that "the brightest flames burn the quickest".Lucas Jackson is just that, he is nothing but a ball of passion, living life as his heart tells him to do. He has lived, he has done horrible things, he has loved, and all with nothing more than an innocent smile on his face. He did only what he felt was right.But, burning with such passion has it's own negatives... even though he inspires everyone around him, for every ounce of passion he inspires, it seems that twice as much passion is ripped from him. As he creates life, his own life is drained...It is a story about selflessness. It is about a man who gives all of himself despite the toll taken upon himself. It is a story about a man doing whatever he has to do, no matter what the risks.
